yeah so federated learning is a promising approach that has been recently introduced with the idea of
bringing ml to the edge and this not only helps to prevent preserve the privacy of raw data but
also helps to cut down the transmission overheads in wireless communications and let us take
a look at how this works traditionally ml models required for
autonomous driving have been built by using sensors on the edge to collect data that are transmitted to a central server
for model training and once the model has been trained the model parameters are sent back to the
edge devices for prediction purposes however to train very large deep neural
networks that are robust to deal with a range of corner cases we need to keep updating the model using
large amounts of diverse data that's being continuously collected by vehicle fleets
and now transmitting large amounts of data from edge devices to the cloud for model training
can introduce unacceptable costs delays and can also infringe on privacy
and as you see here what happens in federated learning is that data is collected locally on the
edge devices and instead of transmitting the entire data to the cloud for training in a centralized server
models are trained locally on the edge and only the parameters or the gradients of the
of the learnable parameters derived from the local data sets are sent to the cloud
and the server aggregates the gradients from all the edge devices and determines the final model parameters
and those are sent back to the edge devices for inference and this is repeated iteratively to
continue to fine tune the model till the desired accuracy is reached
so compute everywhere this is so amazing and so interesting really and uh can't wait to see it uh as

at the evolution of deep neural networks because that directly relates with the motivation for distributed learning
neural networks have been around since the 1960s but they were mostly shallow networks
with a small number of layers and small number of neurons in each layer however for learning very complex
problems you need very deep neural networks that contain several layers and require a large amount of training
data to get the best accuracy on the desired inference task and in the last decade with the
increased access to large volume of data and advanced gpu architectures deep learning has become increasingly
popular but as the gpu architectures have been evolving so have been the complexity of the
problems we're trying to solve using the deep neural networks and training large networks is
computationally expensive and can take an impractically long time if you're using a single machine even if
it supports multi-threading and this inspired distributed training where the training of these models is
scaled across multiple connected gpu clusters in a distributed manner
so i get it that it makes a lot of sense distributed training is accelerates your time to to train a
model but you know how is sagemaker actually supporting that and making it easier for
our customers yeah there are two types of parallelism one can think of when it comes to
distributed learning uh one is data parallelism and the other is model parallelism and sagemaker distributed training uh
distributed library offers two options for distributed training one is called data parallel and
the other is model parallel to support these and before going into examples of how sagemaker is supporting these
let us understand what these two types of parallelism mean so data parallelism is a way to train on
really large data sets by splitting training data and distributing it to multiple worker
machines and each worker machine has a complete copy of the same model and it trains its own
model and the model weights are aggregated in the central parameter server
and there are many algorithms used for averaging and but one of the simplest one is called parameter averaging
the updated global parameters are broadcasted to the worker machines for the next iteration of training
and a variation of this is the asynchronous stochastic gradient descent where instead of the parameters
only the parameter updates are transmitted and this is called asynchronous since each worker machine communicates with
the central server independently of the others whoa wait a minute suchi
this stuff's getting a bit heavy um are you saying that this is a feature of sagemaker or an optimization in the algorithms
deployed on the gpu instances or is there a competitive advantage to sagemaker here
yeah but with sagemaker's distributed training libraries up to 90 of the gpu resources can now be
used for training and not for data transfer so we can achieve near linear scaling efficiency
regardless of the number of gpus involved so in other words if a training job runs for eight hours on a single instance
it'll only take approximately one hour on eight instances with minimum cost increase
and sagemaker effectively eliminates any trade-off between training cost and training time
allowing ml teams to get results sooner i trade faster and accelerate the innovation
and to add to this sagemaker's data parallel library uses the all reduce algorithm where the
gpus don't talk to one another anymore and each stores its gradient updates in
the gpu memory and when a certain threshold is exceeded these updates are
you know are sent to the parameter server running on the cpus of the gpu instances and this removes the need for dedicated
parameter servers and each cpu is responsible for a subset of the model parameters
and it receives updates coming from all the gpus for example with three training instances equipped with a single gpu
each gpu in the training cluster would send a third of its gradient updates to each one of the three cpus
similarly each cpu would apply all the gradient updates that it received and this would distribute
um the consolidated results back to to the gpus
uh that's uh that's pretty amazing i mean it's just basic sharing uh you know across multiple
machines it sounds like a simple concept but it takes quite a bit to implement

machine and the framework that supports model parallelism needs to be automatically
it automatically needs to manage the communication between the nodes and synchronize the training or the inference process
